content.title: Extent IV Thoracoabdominal Aortic Aneurysm
content.description: Thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm extending from the diaphragm to the aortic bifurcation, involving all visceral vessels but sparing the descending thoracic aorta.
content.definition: Crawford Extent IV TAAA involves the entire abdominal aorta from the diaphragmatic hiatus to the aortic bifurcation, requiring reconstruction of celiac, SMA, and renal arteries. Often overlaps conceptually with suprarenal AAA but traditionally classified separately when involving the supraceliaic segment.

anatomic_extent: Involves: Celiac, SMA, both renal arteries
surgical_approach: All four visceral vessels require reconstruction
outcomes: Spinal cord ischemia risk: 2-5% (lowest of TAAA)
Bowel ischemia: Uncommon with proper technique

learning_objectives: Understand lowest spinal cord risk among TAAAs
Compare open vs branched EVAR approaches
clinical_pearls: Extent IV has lowest cord ischemia risk because descending aorta preserved
Preoperative CT must assess patency of celiac, SMA, and both renals
Fenestrated EVAR for Extent IV requires 4-vessel fenestrations/scallops
Hybrid approach: Visceral debranching through midline, then standard TEVAR
